Nothing in this video is incorrect, but I feel that it could mislead people into painting the entirety of our species' past with a "sick and hungry" brush. As we move towards the future, most of us are quick to forget the lessons taught by history and the wisdom held by cultures that simply aren't around anymore. There are a great many problems today which peoples of the past could never imagine due to globalisation, the Internet, etc.

I also wonder whether or not it's such a good thing that there are so many less sick and hungry today; there are so many people around that our planet does not have the resources to provide them all with a standard of living equitable to what we remember the American middle class used to resemble. Therefore, either poverty or death is a necessity on a grand scale. It furthermore is not like most of these 7.6B people (holy shit when I was a kid it was 6!) are particularly useful in any way, with one portion doing little but producing in a slave-like manner for the other, as that part of humanity parasitically consumes while bitching about their gas prices or their safe space or whatever bullshit.

Being obese does NOT preclude one from being malnourished. In fact, one is far more likely to be malnourished and obese than to be malnourished and underweight, simply from a statistical standpoint. In the US, obesity and poverty are incredibly strongly linked. It is cheaper to buy pre-pacakged rubbish than it is to buy fresh produce & meats, which leads to malnutrition. Malnutrition is characterised by the lack of essential nutients (vitamins, minerals, amino acids, etc) in one's diet, which increases alarmingly the more heavily one needs to rely on pre-packaged foods to survive. It costs a lot of money to remain within a few points of one's ideal physical shape. We are not necessarily better or worse off than our ancestors, we just have a different set of challenges to face.

Guys, our ancestors were not stupid. Some people thought the Bubonic Plague was 'demons,' but most knew that it was a disease - that's why they quarantined infected areas, burned bodies and so on. Granted, the germ theory of disease didn’t exist yet, but that doesn't mean they thought it had a supernatural cause (outside of God 'allowing it to happen' or whatever).

Malnutrition doesn't mean "starvation." It's polar opposite is not "being overweight" (or obese). In fact, it is absolutely, entirely possible currently for a poor person in a first world country to be BOTH overweight/obese AND malnurished (that is, lacking nutrients). This can happen as people attempt to lose weight while not being able to afford healthy food or supplements, but more disturbingly it can happen - including to children (who are sometimes overlooked for programs if overweight as not needing the food) who get plenty of empty calories or low-nutrition food but little actual nutrients (even protein at times) - in the form of countless deficiencies which can still kill if untreated.
